content: BOUNDARY MODIFICATION, MORLEY NELSON SNAKE RIVER BIRDS OF PREY NATIONAL CONSERVATION AREA, IDAHO. Definitions for the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area include terms like Conservation Area, Gateway West, Map, Sage-grouse species, and Secretary. The Secretary of the Interior is defined as the "Secretary." The Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area boundary is modified to include specific acres of land managed by BLM until terms of a settlement agreement are met. The Secretary of the Interior modifies the Morley Nelson Snake River Birds of Prey National Conservation Area boundary to include specific BLM-managed lands, while excluding certain acres for the Gateway West Transmission Line project. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for construction and maintenance of transmission lines, including access roads and fire prevention activities, aligning with revised proposed routes for segments 8 and 9. The Secretary will issue a right-of-way to Gateway West for construction and maintenance of transmission lines in segments 8 and 9. Conditions for the right-of-way include mitigation measures during construction, with costs not to exceed $8,543,440. Gateway West will contribute $2,000 per acre of right-of-way in the Conservation Area for the construction of Segment 8 and Segment 9 Revised Proposed Route. They will also pay for all costs associated with the boundary modification, including surveys and recording costs. The Secretary will administer lands in the Conservation Area according to specific laws and continue to manage other lands separately. Administrative jurisdiction over 86 acres is transferred from the Bureau of Reclamation to the Bureau of Land Management. The Secretary will amend the management plan for the Conservation Area within 18 months to address long-term management of specific lands, including grazing activities, in accordance with relevant laws. The map of the area will be available for public inspection at Bureau of Land Management offices. Grazing, motorized access on existing roads, hunting, and fishing will be allowed on the lands described in subsection (b)(1) with reasonable regulations set by the Secretary. The Cotterel Wind Power Project area on approximately 203 acres of Federal land is prohibited from being used for wind electricity production. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation is addressed in the following section. The Secretary of the Interior will establish a Bureau of Land Management Foundation as a charitable nonprofit corporation to address specific challenges such as reclamation of legacy wells, sustainable management of wild horses, and expanded scientific understanding. The Bureau of Land Management Foundation will focus on sustainable management of wild horses, expanded scientific understanding, voluntary conservation activities, and proper identification of cultural and historical treasures on public lands.
